channel.title: VMware Cloud Foundation
channel.generator: Webpage HTML Export plugin for Obsidian

item.title: vSphere and vCenter
item.description:
vSphere is the platform (the whole virtualization stack) vCenter Server is the control plane that manages the coordinates of that platform ESXi is the hypervisor that runs on hardware and executes VMs. I mentally see (but don’t tell) this as “vSphere is just marketing”: There is nothing I can curl called vSphere. it is “air”. VMware vSphere is a product suite, not a single binary.To be clear: vSphere is a product name, or a platform name. Its components are the concrete things that actually do the work.vSphere includes: ESXi is the bare-metal hypervisor.
vCenter Server provides centralized management. Platform features: vMotion (live VM migration) HA/DRS Resource pools Distributed switches Storage policies Fault tolerance You cannot have vSphere without ESXi. You can have ESXi without vCenter (but it will be very limited). Connects many ESXi hosts. Maintains inventory and state Enforces cluster-level logic. Orchestrates features that require coordination. vMotion between hosts DRS placement decisions Cluster HA Supervisor Cluster (for Kubernetes / VCF) vCenter Server is a set of backend services: Inventory (hosts, clusters, VMs) State and configuration database
Scheduling logic (DRS)
HA coordination
vMotion orchestration RBAC, roles, permissions APIs (REST, SOAP)

There is exactly ONE UI name (“vSphere Client”), but it can connect to TWO different backends. vSphere Server ESXi Hosts ## Mode 1 Browser ↓ ESXi Host ↓ Embedded vSphere Client ## Mode 2 Browser ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere Client ↓ Many ESXi hosts
A vSphere Cluster is a logical grouping of ESXi hosts that vCenter treats as a single resource pool and failure domain. It exists only in vCenter ESXi hosts do not know they are “in a cluster”. When you create a cluster in vCenter Server, you are telling: “*These ESXi hosts agree to be scheduled, balanced, and failed over together.”This enables cluster-level logic, such as DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler): vCenter decides which host should run which VM. When to rebalance the load.
Uses vMotion to move VMs between hosts. HA (High Availability) Hosts run a lightweight HA agent. If a host dies: Other hosts detect it vCenter (or preconfigured HA logic) restarts VMs elsewhere. Shared resource abstraction Instead of thinking: Host A: 64 cores Host B: 64 cores vCenter presents Cluster: 128 cores VM placement and limits are logical, not physical.A vSphere Cluster is not:Because from an operator’s perspective: Hosts act like a pool Failures are absorbed Workloads move transparently But architecturally: The cluster is an illusion created by vCenter.
A vSphere cluster is a vCenter-defined scheduling and failure domain over multiple ESXi hosts,[ Physical Servers ] ↓ ESXi (many hosts) ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere features & automation

item.title: Tenants in Supervisor
item.description:
#tenancy In vSphere Supervisor a tenant is namespace-bound. There is no separate tenant object inside Kubernetes.
A Supervisor Namespace is the tenant boundary at the vSphere-Kubernetes interface. If you assume: Tenant = Project → you’ll design the wrong thing Tenant = Kubernetes namespace → you’ll under-secure Tenant = Supervisor Namespace → things line up “tenant namespace” is an informal shorthand for supervisor namespace. Organizations and Projects are governance overlays. They do not define the tenant.Kubernetes namespaces inside guest clusters are secondary scopes.In vSphere Supervisor each tenant is realized as one (or more) Supervisor namespaces. VCF Automation sits above, provides governance (Organizations, Projects, quotas) and self-service, but does not define tenancy by itself.This is sometimes “informally” expressed as “tenant namespaces”. What is meant by it is a Supervisor Namespace.Or more precisely: In a Supervisor Cluster tenant == supervisor namespace (there is a 1-1 relationship).
In vSphere Supervisor, tenancy is realized through Supervisor Namespaces, which serve as the execution and isolation boundary for tenants.When people say: “tenant namespace” “project namespace” “customer namespace” They almost always mean: A Supervisor Namespace allocated to that tenant. Kubernetes does not have a separate construct for this: It is a vSphere concept, projected as a namespace.A Supervisor Namespace can contain: Pods VMs Entire guest Kubernetes clusters Tenant └── Supervisor Namespace ├── VM workloads ├── Pod workloads └── Guest K8s Cluster └── many Kubernetes namespaces VCF Environment └── vSphere (vCenter) └── Supervisor Cluster └── Supervisor Namespace ← TENANT BOUNDARY At this layer: Supervisor Namespace Has: Resource limits Storage policies Network segments RBAC bindings Is created and owned by vCenter Maps to: Resource pools NSX constructs Datastore permissions This is where hard multitenancy lives.

#tenancy This is logical tenancy, not execution tenancy.Organization └── Project └── Deployment / Blueprint └── (Targets a Supervisor Namespace) Organization Business / administrative grouping Project Quota + governance container These map downwards, but they don’t execute workloads themselves.
Supervisor Namespace defines a tenant from a runtime and security perspective.
At VCF-A Organizations and Projects define: Ownership Billing
Governance Access workflows But not execution boundaries. VCF Environment (Rackspace) └── Supervisor Cluster ├── ns-cocacola ← Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-pepsi ← Tenant: Pepsi └── ns-pizzahut ← Tenant: Pizza Hut Each tenant is a supervisor namespace.
For Coca-Cola (example): Fixed CPU / memory quota Dedicated or isolated NSX segment Approved storage policies RBAC scoped to Coca-Cola admins Ability to run: Pods VMs Guest Kubernetes clusters That namespace is the tenant boundary. Layer VCF automation on top of this:Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke-Prod └── Deployments → targets ns-cocacola Organization: Pepsi └── Project: Pepsi-Shared └── Deployments → targets ns-pepsi Organizations and Projects map to Supervisor Namespaces — they do not replace them.Automation gives: Self-service catalogs Approval workflows Policy as code Lifecycle orchestration But the tenant still “lives” at the Supervisor Namespace.Scope vCenter Supervisor Cluster NSX Storage policies Responsibilities Create Supervisor Namespaces Set quotas Attach networks Bind tenant identities Enforce platform guardrails Power level God-mode Not visible to customers Scope One Supervisor Namespace (e.g., ns-cocacola) Kubernetes API within that namespace Responsibilities Manage workloads Deploy guest clusters Configure service Delegate access internally Cannot See other tenants Modify quotas Escape namespace This is who you hand the kubeconfig to. Scope Kubernetes RBAC inside tenant (supervisor) namespace Possibly inside guest clusters Responsibilities Deploy apps Manage services Consume secrets No infrastructure privileges Scope Automation policies Catalogs Projects Approvals This role: Often held by Rackspace Sometimes delegated partially to tenants
#secrets Secrets do not cross Supervisor Namespaces Identity trust roots often terminate there Network policy enforcement happens there Audit logs are scoped there So when you say tenant == Supervisor Namespace, then: Security Compliance Billing Automation all align clearly.

item.title: Supervisor-Namespace
vSphere construct
item.description:
A vSphere construct is: *A first-class infrastructure object that is _natively defined, owned, and enforced by the vSphere control plane (ESXi + vCenter), not by Kubernetes or higher-level automation layers. Think of it as a primitive in vSphere’s own vocabulary.Below are objects that exist because vSphere exists — they are not abstractions layered on top. Virtual Machine vCPU vNUMA vApp Resource Pool Shares / Limits / Reservations DRS rules HA admission control Datastore vSAN object VM disk (VMDK) Storage policy Port Group Distributed Virtual Switch VM NIC VLAN / overlay constructs Snapshot Clone vMotion Storage vMotion HA restart Fault Tolerance All of these are authoritative in VMware vSphere and enforced by: VMware ESXi VMware vCenter Server These are foreign concepts to vSphere — it may host them, but it does not own them: Kubernetes Pod Kubernetes Deployment Kubernetes Service Kubernetes ReplicaSet Kubernetes Namespace (in the K8s sense) Kubernetes ServiceAccount vSphere sees these as resource consumers, not objects with meaning.A VM Workload is built entirely out of vSphere constructs.
A Pod Workload is built out of Kubernetes constructs, even though it ultimately consumes vSphere resources.## VM Workload VM ├─ vCPU ├─ vMemory ├─ VMDK ├─ Port Group └─ Resource Pool Pod ├─ Container ├─ CPU request/limit ├─ Memory request/limit ├─ ServiceAccount └─ Namespace

item.title: VM Workload and Pod Workload
item.description:
In VCF, a workload is: A unit of compute that consumes CPU, memory, storage, and networking, and is subject to lifecycle, policy, and governance. VCF doesn’t care what the workload is at a philosophical level. It cares about: How it is instantiated How it is isolated How it is scheduled How it is governed Which control plane owns it one machine per workloadA VM workload is a traditional virtual machine: Runs on ESXi Has its own guest OS Is managed by vCenter Uses vSphere constructs directly vCenter Server is the authoritative control plane VCF Automation wraps vCenter, but does not replace it CPU / memory allocated per VM Strong isolation via hypervisor boundaries Overcommitment controlled at ESXi level Create VM Power on/off Snapshot Clone Patch guest OS Backup VM image VM policies Placement rules Affinity / anti-affinity HA / DRS Backup & DR policies many disposable units forming a service.A pod workload is a Kubernetes Pod running on the vSphere Supervisor Cluster.A pod on the vSphere Supervisor Cluster is not a traditional Kubernetes pod. It is a vSphere Pod — Kubernetes-shaped, but vSphere-implemented.Key point: A pod workload is not a VM pretending to be a container. Supervisor pods are VMs implementing container semantics, not containers implemented as VMs. A Supervisor pod is a Kubernetes Pod whose execution unit is a micro-VM, where the VM boundary replaces the Linux container boundary. The VM is the isolation primitive The Pod is the semantic primitive The container image is payload, not a process model So the VM is not “pretending to be a container” — it is implementing the Pod abstraction using a VM instead of a process. Pod (Kubernetes API object) └─ Backed by └─ Ultra-lightweight VM └─ ESXi └─ Hardware It is: A Kubernetes-native unit Scheduled by Kubernetes Governed by Kubernetes APIs Backed by vSphere under the hood Kubernetes API (Supervisor cluster) is authoritative vCenter supplies infrastructure, not lifecycle semantics VCF Automation governs Kubernetes intent, not individual pods CPU / memory requested via Kubernetes requests & limits Scheduler decides placement Isolation via: Namespaces RBAC Pod security (Optionally) VM-backed pod runtimes Declarative (YAML) Reconciliation-based Pods are ephemeral Restart ≠ failure Replacement is normal Namespace-level quotas Admission control Image policies Network policies VM workloads → legacy, stateful, pet-like systems Pod workloads → cloud-native, stateless, cattle-like systems VCF’s value is: Running both on the same physical infrastructure, with unified policy and automation, without forcing one model onto the other. Trying to manage pods like VMs breaks Kubernetes. Trying to manage VMs like pods breaks operational reality.VCF keeps them separate but coordinated.
A pod workload in VCF is a Kubernetes-native execution unit scheduled and governed by the vSphere Supervisor Kubernetes control plane, consuming vSphere resources indirectly through Kubernetes abstractions—unlike a VM workload, which is a hypervisor-managed, OS-bearing unit directly governed by vCenter. “Pod workload” ≠ “small VM” Pod workloads are Kubernetes-first, not vSphere-first VMs are stateful machines Pods are replaceable execution instances VCF supports both because enterprises need both

item.title: vSphere Supervisor
item.description:
The vSphere Supervisor lives as a set of Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESXi hosts, instantiated, wired, and governed by vCenter Server.
Runs on: VMware ESXi Created and managed by: VMware vCenter Server Implemented as: Kubernetes control-plane VMs
Distributed across ESXi hosts
Backed by vSAN / datastores
Networked via NSX (or VDS in simpler setups) When you “enable Supervisor” in vCenter: vCenter: Creates a special-purpose Kubernetes cluster Instantiates its control plane as VMs Pins it tightly to: Cluster membership Networking Storage Treats it as part of the infrastructure, not a tenant workload So the Supervisor is: Not a workload cluster Not user-managed Kubernetes Not a vSphere product you install It is an infrastructure service owned by vCenter.Physical Hosts └─ ESXi └─ vCenter Server (control plane) └─ Supervisor Cluster (Kubernetes control plane VMs) ├─ Supervisor Namespaces ├─ vSphere Pods └─ Guest / Workload Clusters The vSphere Supervisor is a Kubernetes control plane deployed as system-managed VMs on ESXi, whose lifecycle is owned entirely by vCenter Server and whose purpose is to expose Kubernetes semantics directly on vSphere infrastructure. The vSphere Supervisor physically lives as vCenter-managed Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESXi hosts inside a vSphere cluster.
vSphere Supervisor is the foundation of VCF consumption and can be enabled during workload domain creation or directly in vCenter.
#todo "consumption" is discussed in several meetings. It seems like standard nomenclature. Learn what it is.
#todo Is vSphere Supervisor a type of vSphere deployment. Follow-up: what really is vSphere? Is it part of VCF-A or VCF-O? It transforms vSphere clusters into modern application platforms by embedding a platform-level Kubernetes control plane directly into ESX hosts, exposing a unified declarative API surface.
This integration allows end users to provision and manage workloads, including VMs, containers via vSphere Pods, full Kubernetes clusters through VKS, OCI image registries, and data services through a consistent API interface.
#todo what kinds or registries, "bring your own", harbor, cloud? all?
#todo why embedding the control plane into ESX hosts is such a big thing? wasn't that possible before. Isn't an ESXi a "linux machine" at a high level anyway? What makes this so unique and innovative?
#todo is the "unified declarative API surface" k8s API, and custom resources? What kind(s) of Custom Resources?
#todo what "really" is a vSphere Pod? Enough with all the marketing language!
vSphere Supervisor maintains enterprise-grade governance, security, and operational consistency through vCenter, VCF Operations, and VCF Automation.
#todo is vSphere Supervisor a higher-level abstraction around the above; or is it a separate entity that communicates (i.e. supervises) those sub-entities?
vSphere Supervisor's vSphere Namespaces provide the foundation for multi-tenancy, enabling GitOps-based workflows, and delivering cloud-like self-service in private data centers.
#todo so tenancy is namespace-bound?
#tenancy
Use NSX Virtual Private Clouds (VPC) workload networks. This configuration is a requirement for using VCF Automation
Determine if a Single-Zone Supervisor or Multi-Zone Supervisor deployment is required: In VCF 9.0, a Supervisor deployed in a single-zone configuration cannot be converted to a multi-zone deployment after enablement. You must determine the target deployment model before initiating the Supervisor enablement process.
#todo what is single-zone versus multi-zone? Single-Zone Deployment: A Single-Zone Supervisor deployment uses a single vSphere cluster to host both workloads and Supervisor management components.
Additional vSphere Zones can be added after initial enablement. However, these zones are used exclusively for workload placement and do not host Supervisor control plane components.
#todo what are Supervisor control plane components?
Multi-Zone Deployment: A Multi-Zone Supervisor deployment uses three vSphere clusters, placing each cluster into a vSphere Zone. vSphere Zones are used by workloads and Supervisor management components to deliver high availability and expose each cluster as an independent, consumable availability zone. This configuration provides a resilient, HA-capable platform. Additional vSphere Zones can be added after initial enablement. However, these additional zones are available for workload consumption only, not for Supervisor control plane components. Single Host: Also a Single-Zone Supervisor with a single Control Plane VM deployed to a single ESX host, with vSphere HA disabled. While it shares the same characteristics as other single-zone deployments, in this configuration, any host failure results in downtime for the Supervisor Control Plane and potentially for associated workloads.
Easy Supervisor: This is a Single-Zone simplified deployment that uses workload networking on top of vSphere Distributed Switch, designed as a fast and simple starting point for proof-of-concept environments and production deployments leveraging vSphere Distributed Switch. An Easy Supervisor deployment consists of: One Supervisor Control Plane VM A shared network for both workload and management traffic No load balancer
#todo does that imply that normally workload and management traffic is spilt?
It is vSphere running in special Kubernetes-enabled mode.
VCF Automation consumes what Supervisor exposes.
You can think of Supervisor as vSphere with Kubernetes fused into its control plane.


When you enable Supervisor on a vSphere cluster, you are activating a capability inside vSphere.
Supervisor runs inside ESXi.
Uses vCenter as the control plane.
Creates Supervisor Namespaces. Exposes Kubernetes APIs, backed by native vSphere primitives. So conceptually, Supervisor is vSphere operating in "Kubernetes-native mode".
Supervisor Namespaces are not Kubernetes namespaces.If classic vSphere is "run VMs", Supervisor vSphere is "Run anything (VMs, Pods, services)" with the same primitives.
Supervisor runs on ESXi. It enables Kubernetes semantics backed by vSphere primitives.
VCF Automation is optional and sits above Supervisor.
Supervisor Namespaces look like Kubernetes namespace on purpose.

item.title: Governance
item.description: Governance in VCF is the set of mechanisms that decide who is allowed to request which platform capabilities, under what constraints, with what approvals, and for how long — before anything is created.What Governance is not:Governance does not watch workloads. It decides whether they are allowed to exist in the first place.Governance (VCF Automation) ├── Organizations ├── Projects ├── Blueprints ├── Entitlements ├── Approvals ├── Quotas └── Leases Execution (vSphere / Supervisor) ├── Namespaces ├── Resource pools ├── Networks └── Workloads Nothing in the execution layer knowns governance exists. Governance defines who may open the door. Execution decides what happens after they are inside the house. In other words, governance is “pre-creation” control, not runtime policing.

item.title: vSphere Client
item.description: VMware vSphere Client is: A web UI (HTML5 / JS) Running inside either ESXi or vCenter Consuming backend APIs It consumes REST and legacy SOAP / internal APIs Functionally: It is an API consumer It behaves differently depending on where it is placed: Same UI codebase: Connected to ESXi → host-scoped Connected to vCenter Server → environment-scoped The UI is not “smart”: The backend defines reality.vSphere is a product contract, not a system. ESXi and vCenter are the systems that implement that contract.

item.title: What-is-VMware-vSphere-vSphere-Client
Kubectl in Supervisorlandia
item.description:
Connected to Supervisor Cluster:kubectl config use-context <supervisor-context> kubectl get ns NAME STATUS AGE default Active kube-system Active kube-public Active kube-node-lease Active my-team-a Active my-team-b Active Here, there is no such thing as a “regular Kubernetes namespace” in the tenant sense. The namespace here: Cannot be created freely. Map to vSphere inventory objects. Quotas, storage, and networking are externally-enforced. Connected to a guest clusterkubectl get ns kubectl create ns foo kubectl delete ns foo All of these will work as expected. Supervisor namespaces → owns the cluster. Guest cluster namespace → normal Kubernetes semantics. # check Supervisor-specific APIs kubectl api-resources | grep -i vm virtualmachines vmoperator.vmware.com # look at the nodes kubectl get nodes -o wide # look for VM Operator kubectl get pods -A | grep vmoperator Supervisor cluster nodes typically show: ESXi-backed control-plane VMs. Special node labels VM Operator components Guest clusters look like: Standard linux nodes kubelet-managed lifecycle No VM Operator CRDs. In a Supervisor cluster, tenant namespaces are Kubernetes namespaces whose lifecycle, limits, and security are owned by vSphere. In a guest cluster, namespaces are owned entirely by Kubernetes.
#tenancy

item.title: Supervisor Namespace
item.description:
These are not Kubernetes namespaces in the usual sense. They are: Resource-governed containers Backed by: vSphere Networking (NSX)
vSphere Storage (VSAN) vSphere RBAC From vSphere's perspective, a Pod, VM, or VM-based Pod is just scheduled compute.Supervisor namespaces intentionally mimic Kubernetes semantics:From the developer's laptop, they feel like ordinary Kubernetes namespaces.Here is where they differ though (mostly around ownership and LCM)in Supervisor namespaces, resource governance is outside Kubernetes.In Kubernetes: CPU/memory limits = ResourceQuota Storage = StorageClass + PVC Network = CNI rules In Supervisor: CPU/memory = vSphere resource pools Storage = datastore policies Network = NSX segments Limits are hard boundaries, not advisory So when you say: "This namespace gets 8 vCPU and 64 GB RAM" That's not a Kubernetes promise---that's vSphere enforcing physics.Security model is in vSphere, not in KubernetesKubernetes RBAC applies inside the box vSphere already drew.That’s why certain Kubernetes admin actions are silently blocked even when RBAC says “allowed”.From Kubernetes’ POV: It looks like a CNI plugin In reality: NSX owns: L2/L3 segments Firewall rules Load balancers Kubernetes asks politely. NSX decides.This matters for: NetworkPolicy Ingress behavior Multi-tenant isolation In vanilla K8s: PVC requests storage Cluster tries to satisfy it In Supervisor: PVC must map to pre-approved storage policies Datastore capabilities are enforced externally StorageClass ≈ view of vSphere policy, not a free-form construct.The goal of this abstraction is to: Let Kubernetes users feel at home Let infrastructure teams retain determinism Avoid “Kubernetes ate my datacenter” chaos So Supervisor namespaces are: Kubernetes-compatible interfaces to vSphere-owned sandboxes Supervisor namespaces intentionally impersonate Kubernetes namespaces Kubernetes sees them as native; operations are externally enforced vSphere owns: lifecycle resource limits security boundaries Kubernetes operates within those constraints

item.title: vSphere Supervisor Services and Standalone Components
item.description:
Create declarative workloads and upstream Kubernetes clusters by using vSphere Kubernetes Service and Supervisor Services.
Supervisor Namespace

item.description: Drag from below or double clickSpace + Drag to panCtrl + Scroll to zoom

item.title: ks-ns
Why Does Supervisor Exist
item.description: Kubernetes didn’t replace VMs. It replaced application scheduling semantics.VMware’s bet was: "Instead of forcing Kubernetes to run on top of vSphere, we'll make Kubernetes a native execution mode of vSphere." Supervisor is that bet made concrete. vSphere = substrate Supervisor = Kubernetes-native personality of vSphere VCF Automation = enterprise automation layer on top vSphere Supervisor

item.title: vSphere
item.description:
At its core, it is a compute, storage, and network abstraction layer: A distributed operating system for data centers.It manages large collections of infrastructure, such as CPUs, storage, networking, GPUs, and DPUs as a seamless and dynamic operating environment, and also manages the complexity of a data center.  It virtualizes physical infrastructure into managed CPU, storage, and networking resources.vSphere is a distributed system that provides the following;vSphere is a datacenter operating system.The two core components of VMware vSphere: ESX
and vCenter
High Availability with vSphere automatically restarts your VMs following physical machine failure.
Fault Tolerance provides continuous availability of any application in the event of a hardware failure with no data loss or downtime.
vMotion enables live migration of virtual machines with no disruption to users or loss of service, eliminating the need to schedule application downtime for planned server maintenance. Storage vMotion avoids downtime for planned storage maintenance. Identity federation with Microsoft Entra ID, ADFS and Okta. Virtual Machine Encryption: Data-at-rest encryption for virtual machine data and disks.
vSphere Trust Authority: Remote attestation for sensitive workloads.

item.title: Supervisor-VCF-A Relationshipt
item.description: ┌────────────────────────────┐ │ VCF Automation (vRA) │ ← lifecycle, blueprints, polic ├────────────────────────────┤ │ vSphere Supervisor │ ← Kubernetes-native control plane ├────────────────────────────┤ │ vSphere (ESXi + vCenter) │ ← compute, storage, networking ├────────────────────────────┤ │ Hardware │ └────────────────────────────┘ Supervisor: Exposes Kubernetes + VM APIs Owns runtime enforcement VCF Automation: Consumes Supervisor APIs Provides self-service, governance, orchestration Supervisor enables capabilities VCF Automation operationalizes themvSphere

item.title: The Big Picture
item.description:
The provider administrator can create projects, assign users and groups, and allocate quotas to restrict the configurations available to the tenants.
By creating projects, you can isolate security and networking objects across tenants in a single NSX deployment.
Multi-Tenancy
#tenancyTenants are Bound to ProjectsOutstanding action items: clarify path scheme of secrets understan how organization, projects, tenants, and namespaces tie together. What is a supervisor namespace, what makes it different than a Kubernetes namespace, are there other "namespace" concepts in VCF?

item.title: Provider Management
item.description:
#tenancy
IT teams and CSPs can model Multi-Tenancy by using the concept of Organizations in VCF Automation.
#todo Is a "tenant" organization-bound, or project-bound, or a mixture? This approach allocates resources and manages users specific to each Organization.
#todo in the last one-pager review, Fanny and Stephen recommended the partitioning of the secret path at either project, or namespace level---I don't remember which one. Identify pros/cons of each approach and choose a solution that is aligned with their vision.
This capability provides isolated environments with dedicated network setup. IT Teams and CSPs can monitor resource usage, control permissions, and provide managed services while ensuring security through comprehensive network isolation.

item.title: Organization Management
item.description:
VCF Automation improves governance for users and resources by enabling organization administrators create and assign projects and vSphere Namespaces tailored for different application teams.
#todo make a list of roles and what capabilities each these roles do. For example, "what does an 'organization administrator' do; what are other kinds of admins?"
Organization administrators can set resource limits and policies while delegating network management through Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs) for application teams.
Additionally, Policy as Code enables organization administrators to enforce instance-centric policies for Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) resources from a central location for compliance and reducing the risk of human error.

item.title: Cloud Services
item.description:
VCF Automation (VCF-A) provides a set of cloud services which are accessible on a self-service basis using multiple interfaces, including UI, CLI, and API.
With this interface, users can provision the following types of workloads: VMs Kubernetes workloads Networking Volumes Secret stores Databases Harbor container registries External DNS Certificates AI workloads
Additionally, application teams can also provision resources on a self-service basis from Catalogs which are backed by pre-configured workload templates. These self-service options help developers focus on application development instead of managing the underlying infrastructure.

item.title: VCF Automation
item.description:
enables IT teams and cloud service providers (CSPs) to deliver a self-service private cloud for AI, Kubernetes, and VM-based applications.
The solution simplifies the process of provisioning and scaling a multi-tenant private cloud with out-of-the-box Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) offerings, accelerating the time to market for applications while maintaining control using policy-based governance.
#tenancy VCF Automation has the following capabilities:
Cloud Services: Provides a set of cloud services to meet the needs of application teams
Provider Management: Supports IT teams and cloud service providers to effectively manage, deliver, and scale cloud services across multiple vCenter and VCF instances.
Organization Management: Provides capabilities that enable the organization administrator of a Line of Business or a tenant to further organize and govern resources allocated to them among application teams.
vSphere Supervisor: Provides the capability to run Kubernetes workloads directly on ESX hosts and to create upstream Kubernetes clusters within dedicated namespaces.( #todo: Further explanation needed )

item.title: Security Management
item.description: The security management area of VCF Operations includes capabilities such as Security Operations, Event Auditing, and Compliance Checks. Security Operations: The Security Operations dashboard is designed to provide a comprehensive view of your security posture in VCF. Events Auditing: Event auditing provides visibility into platform interaction changes across the VCF infrastructure and insights into suspicious access events and policy violations. Compliance: Ensure compliance for your VCF infrastructure and cloud environments against optimum configurations, maintaining a consistent configuration across SDDC components, reducing organizational and business risk.

item.title: Workload Mobility
item.description: VCF Operations HCX is a workload mobility platform for migration and interconnection of workloads within and across VCF private clouds.You can perform secure and automated migrations without requiring changes to applications or network configurations. Important features include multiple migration types, such as live and bulk migration, as well as network extension, which preserves existing IP addresses and network topologies. Thus, you can place workloads based on business requirements. The platform minimizes downtime during migrations, improves scalability, and supports compliance and security throughout workload transitions.

item.title: Workload Placement
item.description: Is the vMotion, or is there something more?

item.title: FinOps and Capacity
item.description:
Cost management helps you analyze your infrastructure expenses. In this way, you can identify areas that are most suitable to use capacity management for optimal utilization of your resources.You can use the FinOps or cost management capabilities to monitor infrastructure-related costs and associated services or license expenses with greater precision.Capacity Management consists of 3 sets of capabilities: assess, optimize and plan.Capacity optimization helps you right-size or reclaim any underutilized or wasted resources.
Workload Placement lets you optimize virtual machines and storage across clusters to reduce resource contention and maintain optimum system performance. By using What-If Analysis, you can plan for an increase or decrease in workload or capacity requirements in your virtual infrastructure.

item.title: cost management
item.description: is FinOps and Capacity

item.title: Performance Monitoring
item.description: Performance monitoring ensures applications have continuous access to resources and AI-driven troubleshooting and remediation enables faster time to resolution of issues while keeping costs down. Manage, monitor and troubleshoot your applications by collecting application metrics from your virtual machines. A VCF Operations management pack, is a software package that allows you to monitor, manage, and troubleshoot infrastructure by collecting metrics, events, and alerts from the integrated system.

item.title: Workload Operations
item.description: Workload operations ensure that critical applications are running properly by monitoring its performance, availability and end-user experience. For container-based applications, VCF Operations provides native integration with vSphere Supervisor which enables automatic monitoring of Supervisor instances and vSphere Kubernetes Service (VKS) clusters at a granular level, shortening troubleshooting time.

item.title: Operations Management
item.description: VCF Operations provides capabilities designed to monitor, diagnose, and manage the health and security of your VCF environments, providing real-time insights and long-term strategic guidance. VCF Health Diagnostics Log Analysis Network Operations Storage Operations

item.title: VCF Operations
item.description:
VCF Operations helps your organization build, manage, operate and secure your private cloud infrastructure by deploying and maintaining its fleet-level components, providing visibility and enhanced performance across the workload and infrastructure stack, and helping your organization stay compliant with regulatory standards and organizational guidelines.VCF-O has these functional areas: Fleet Management Enables operational consistency and efficient resource management of the VCF infrastructure at scale.
Operations Management Provides monitoring and optimization of performance, cost and capacity, and faster troubleshooting.
Workload Operations  Ensures that critical applications are running as expected.
Performance Monitoring Ensures applications have continuous access to resources
FinOps and Capacity Helps you analyze your infrastructure expenses and optimize capacity usage.
Workload Mobility Provides support for migrating and interconnecting workloads within and across VCF private cloud.
Security Management Provides security management to ensure that your VCF private cloud is operationally secure.

item.title: NSX
item.description:
NSX enables network connectivity, operations, and scale. It uses a software-defined approach to networking that spans data centers, clouds and application frameworks.NSX brings networking services closer to the application, whether running on virtual machines (VMs), containers or physical servers. This allows for a cloud operating model where networks can be provisioned and managed independently of the underlying hardware.NSX abstracts network services from the underlying hardware, enabling programmable infrastructure through APIs. You can implement policies and workflows to automate tasks like network provisioning, security enforcement, load balancing, streamlining operations, and improving efficiency.NSX provides a complete set of logical networking capabilities and services, including logical switching, routing, distributed load balancing, virtual private network (VPN), quality of service (QoS), and monitoring.Enable logical Layer 2 overlay extensions across a routed (Layer 3) fabric within and across data center boundaries.Dynamic routing between virtual networks that is performed in a distributed manner in the hypervisor kernel, and scale-out routing with active-active failover with physical routers. Static routing and dynamic routing protocols are supported, including support for IPv6.Complete data plane isolation among tenants with a separate routing table, network address translation (NAT), and edge firewall support in each VRF on the  Support for bridging between VLANs configured on the physical network and NSX overlay networks, for seamless connectivity between virtual and physical workloads.Site-to-site and unmanaged VPN for cloud gateway services.By using NSX, you can move workloads between racks and data centers by decoupling them from the underlying networks.Centralized policy configuration and enforcement across multiple locations from a single pane of glass, enabling network-wide consistent policy, operational simplicity, and simplified disaster recovery architecture. Enable consistent networking and security across data center sites, and across private cloud boundaries, irrespective of underlying physical topology or cloud platform.NSX can manage the provisioning, deployment, operations and retirement of networking infrastructure and applications from a central control pane. You can automate infrastructure operations and offload manual tasks with workflows and agile templating using tools such as VCF Automation, Terraform, and Ansible. 
VPCs provide isolated network environments within a shared infrastructure. You can use Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) constructs to provision and manage network resources to business units or project teams independently, with granular control over networking policies and resource allocation.
By creating projects, you can isolate security and networking objects across tenants in a single NSX deployment. You enable multi-tenant deployment and consumption of NSX services for the provider administrator and the tenants or organizations.
The provider administrator can create projects, assign users and groups, and allocate quotas to restrict the configurations available to the tenants.
#tenancy

item.title: vSAN
item.description:
vSAN aggregates local or direct-attached capacity devices of all ESX hosts in a cluster and creates a single storage poo**l shared across all ESX hosts in the  vSAN cluster.
You can use vSphere features that require shared storage, such as vSphere HA, vSphere vMotion, and vSphere DRS, without the need for external shared storage.vSAN provides operational consistency from edge to cloud, with complete visibility and lifecycle management of compute and storage from a single UI.You can perform consistent, VM-centric operations by using policy-based management. Within the vSAN ESA, per-VM policies increase flexibility of management, enabling compression policies, or customize data services on a per-VM basis.

item.title: VMware Cloud Foundation
item.description:
#mainDesign, plan, deploy, and manage your SDDC by using automation capabilities.
VMware Cloud Foundation is a unified private-cloud platform that combines the scale and agility of public cloud with security and performance of private cloud. delivering increased productivity and lower Total Cost of Ownership (TCO).

item.title: ESX
item.description: is the virtualization platform where you create and run virtual machines and virtual appliances, Kubernetes workloads, and AI/ML workloads.

item.title: What Does VCF Do
item.description: VCF is a full-stack Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) platform that delivers software-defined compute, storage, networking, security, and management. Integrated automation enables a self-service platform to deploy VMs and containers for developer agility. Hardened platform offering built-in resilience, scaling, and clustering for non-stop operations. Provides automation and orchestration to simplify Day 0, Day 1, and Day 2 tasks. Simplifies full stack deployment.
